'''Apple M4''' is an [[ARM architecture family|ARM]]-based [[system on a chip]] (SoC) designed by [[Apple Inc.]], part of the [[Apple silicon]] series, including a [[central processing unit]] (CPU), a [[graphics processing unit]] (GPU), a [[AI accelerator|neural processing unit (NPU)]], and a [[Digital signal processor|digital signal processor (DSP)]]. It was introduced in May 2024 for the [[IPad Pro (7th generation)|iPad Pro (M4)]], and is the fourth generation of the [[Apple Silicon#M series|M series Apple Silicon architecture]], succeeding the [[Apple M3]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Leswing |first=Kif |date=May 7, 2024 |title=Apple announces new iPad Pro with M4, new iPad Air tablets |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2024/05/07/apple-ipad-pro-and-ipad-air-2024-announced.html |access-date=May 8, 2024 |website=CNBC |publisher=NBCUniversal |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Warren |first=Tom |date=May 7, 2024 |title=Next-gen M4 chips start arriving in Apple devices this year |url=https://www.theverge.com/2024/5/7/24148451/apple-m4-chip-ai-ipad-macbook |access-date=May 8, 2024 |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="Apple M4 Press Release">{{Cite press release |title=Apple introduces M4 chip |url=https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/05/apple-introduces-m4-chip/ |publisher=Apple Inc. |language=en-US |location=Cupertino, CA |date=May 7, 2024 |access-date=May 8, 2024}}</ref>

According to Apple, the M4 SoC's Neural Engine is capable of 38 trillion operations per second, "which is 60x faster than Apple’s first Neural Engine in the [[Apple A11|A11 Bionic chip]]." The SoC is built upon a 3-nanometer process, and features 3 or 4 performance cores, 6 efficiency cores, and 10 graphics processing cores.<ref name="Apple iPad Pro 7th Press Release" />

The M4 is the world's fastest consumer SoC in single core performance according to the [[Geekbench]] [[benchmark (computing)|benchmarking]] suite<ref>{{Cite web |last=Norem |first=Josh |date=May 10, 2024 |title=The Apple M4 Is the New Geekbench Single-Core Performance Champion |url=https://www.extremetech.com/computing/the-apple-m4-is-the-new-geekbench-single-core-performance-champion |access-date=May 12, 2024 |website=ExtremeTech |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]]}}</ref>, (beating Apple's M3 Max and Intel's Core i9 desktop CPUs), and rivals Apple's M3 Pro desktop CPU in multi-core performance.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Mayo |first=Benjamin |date=May 11, 2024 |title=iPad Pro with M4 chip boasts impressive performance jump compared to just-released M3 MacBook Air |url=https://9to5mac.com/2024/05/11/ipad-pro-with-m4-chip-geekbench-compared-m3/ |access-date=May 12, 2024 |website=[[9to5Mac]]}}</ref>

It is the first iPad SoC to support AV1 decode, and has a new display controller that Apple claims is necessary to support the [[iPad Pro (7th generation)]]'s Tandem OLED display.<ref name="Apple iPad Pro 7th Press Release" />

It is rumored the Apple M4 is Apple's first SoC which uses the ARMv9 architecture for its CPU cores, ARMv9.4 to be specific.<ref>{{Cite web |title=x.com |url=https://x.com/VadimYuryev/status/1788607053361189307 |access-date=2024-05-21 |website=X (formerly Twitter)}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Mann |first=Tobias |title=You OK, Apple? Seriously, your silicon lineup is a mess |url=https://www.theregister.com/2024/05/13/apple_silicon_roadmap/ |access-date=2024-05-21 |website=www.theregister.com |language=en}}</ref> It also could support Arm's SME2 extension,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Microbenchmarks {{!}} Hello SME documentation |url=https://scalable.uni-jena.de/opt/sme/micro.html |access-date=2024-05-21 |website=scalable.uni-jena.de |language=en}}</ref> which was announced in 2022<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-09-29 |title=Arm A-Profile Architecture Developments 2022 - Architectures and Processors blog - Arm Community blogs - Arm Community |url=https://community.arm.com/arm-community-blogs/b/architectures-and-processors-blog/posts/arm-a-profile-architecture-2022 |access-date=2024-05-21 |website=community.arm.com |language=en}}</ref> and is a superset of SME and SVE2,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Documentation – Arm Developer |url=https://developer.arm.com/documentation/102374/0102/Data-processing---vector-and-matrix-data |access-date=2024-05-21 |website=developer.arm.com}}</ref> to accelerate matrix operations. This is likely the cause of the majority of the estimated 7.6% [[Instructions per cycle|Instructions Per Cycle]] (IPC) uplift from M3 Max, which would only be 3.0% without the new matrix extensions.<ref>{{Cite web |title=x.com |url=https://x.com/toniievych/status/1788600339173703754 |access-date=2024-05-21 |website=X (formerly Twitter)}}</ref>
